Technical Assistance Report 
 
Project Number: 44375  
Project Preparatory Technical Assistance (PPTA)  
September 2011 
 
 
 
Papua New Guinea: Preparing the Maritime and 
Waterways Safety Project 
(Financed by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction)  
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

PROJECT PREPARATORY TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
1.  A project preparatory technical assistance (PPTA) for the proposed project (the project) 
is  needed  to:  (i)  conduct  due  diligence  (i.e.,  technical,  economic,  social  and  poverty  and 
environmental assessments), cost estimation and development of a procurement plan of civil 
works for navigational aids (navaids) improvement; (ii) conduct technical assessments, cost 
estimation and development of a procurement plan of goods, equipment and survey related to 
safety information infrastructure, including automatic identification system and meteorological 
sensors and hydrographic charts; (iii) analyze the National Maritime Safety Authority (NMSA) 
and other stakeholders including communities and ship operators to identify required actions to 
strengthen their operation and technical capacity and thus safety and environmental protection 
in Papua New Guinea (PNG).  
 
B.  Major Outputs and Activities 
2.  The PPTA will carry out field survey and required assessments, including all technical, 
economic, social and poverty, and environmental aspects. Consultants will be engaged to 
produce: (i) due diligence reports, cost estimates and a procurement plan of civil works for 
navaids improvement; (ii) technical assessment reports, cost estimates and a procurement plan 
for goods, equipment and survey related to safety information infrastructure and hydrographic 
charts; and (iii) an institutional capacity development plan to strengthen safety and efficiency 
marine  and  waterways  transport  focusing  on  NMSA  and  other  stakeholders,  including 
communities and shipping operators.

C.  Cost Estimate and Proposed Financing Arrangement  
4.  The PPTA is estimated to cost $800,000 equivalent, of which $600,000 equivalent will 
be financed on a grant basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction, and administered by 
ADB.  The  government  will  finance  the  remaining  $200,000  equivalent  in-kind  through  the 
provision  of  counterpart  staff,  office  space  and  administrative  support,  logistics  and  local 
transport. The detailed cost estimate is presented in Table A4.2. Disbursement under the TA will 
be made in accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as 
amended from time to time).

D.  Consulting Services 
5.  The PPTA will finance the services of eight international consultants for a total period of 
17 person-months for the activities described in para. 2. About 5 months of counterpart staff 
services will be provided by the executing agency (EA), i.e., NMSA. Consultant selection will be 
via quality- and cost-based selection procedures with 80:20 weighting for quality and cost, 
respectively. ADB will engage consulting services for the PPTA in accordance with ADB’s 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time) for the selection 
and engagement of international consultants.

6.  The outline terms of reference (TOR) for the PPTA consultants are described in paras. 7 
to 14.  
 
7.  Maritime Systems Specialist and Team Leader (international, 4 person-months). The 
specialist will design and manage the detailed work program for all aspects of the TA, supervise 
and/or conduct the required analyses and consultations, and develop recommendations and an 
action plan. He/she will verify NMSA’s plan for safety information infrastructure, refine NMSA’s 
function and process related to navaids and provide engineering expertise to improve operation 
and  maintenance  of  navaids.  He/she  will  have  (i)  a  tertiary  degree  in  maritime 
technology/engineering or closely related fields, (ii) at least 8 years experience in development 
projects, and (iii) relevant work experience in Pacific developing member countries (DMCs) or 
similar environments.   
 
8.  Transport/Civil Engineer (international, 2 person-months). The consultant will provide 
technical inputs, including least cost and full life cycle cost estimates for optimal combinations of 
future capital and recurrent expenditures. He/she will have (i) an advanced degree in transport 
or civil engineering or other related fields; (ii) at least 8 years experience in designing and 
analyzing development projects in general, and transport projects in particular; and (iii) relevant 
work experience in Pacific DMCs or similar environments. 
 
9.  Hydrographic Specialist (international, 1.5 person-months). The specialist will design a 
detailed  work  program  for  hydrographic  charts.  He/she  will  have  (i)  a  tertiary  degree  in 
hydrographic  engineering  or  closely  related  fields,  (ii)  at  least  5  years  experience  in 
development  projects,  and  (iii)  relevant  work  experience  in  Pacific  DMCs  or  similar 
environments.   
 
10.  Institutional Specialist (international, 2 person-months). The specialist will design an 
institutional capacity development plan. He/she will have (i) a tertiary degree in social sciences, 
(ii) at least 5 years experience in development projects, and (iii) relevant work experience in 
Pacific DMCs or similar environments.  
 
11.  Environmental Specialist (international, 2 person-months). The specialist will prepare 
the required environmental assessment for subprojects and the overall project and analyze risks 
to environment due to changes in shipping routes, as well as risks to existing infrastructure from 
climate change impacts. He/she will have (i) a tertiary degree in environmental engineering or a 
closely related field, (ii) at least 5 years experience in development projects, and (iii) relevant 
work experience in Pacific DMCs or similar environments.

4   
12.  Social  and  Poverty  Specialist  (international,  2  person-months).  The  specialist  will 
assess social and poverty issues for the project. He/she will have (i) a tertiary degree in social 
sciences,  (ii)  at  least  5  years  experience  in  development  projects,  and  (iii)  relevant  work 
experience in Pacific DMCs or similar environments.  
 
13.  Economist  (international,  1.5  person-months).  The  specialist  will  conduct  economic 
analysis of the overall project to determine its acceptability in terms of economic efficiency and 
sustainability. He/she will have (i) an advanced degree in economics or closely related fields; (ii) 
at least 7 years experience in designing and analyzing development projects in general, and 
transport projects in particular; and (iii) relevant work experience in Pacific DMCs or similar 
environments.   
 
14.  Financial Management Specialist (international, 2.0 person-months). The specialist 
will  conduct  a  financial  due  diligence  exercise  required  by  ADB.  He/she  will  have  (i)  an 
advanced degree in economics or closely related fields; (ii) at least 7 years experience in 
designing and analyzing development projects in general, and transport projects in particular; 
and (iii) relevant work experience in Pacific DMCs or similar environments.  
 
E.  Implementation Arrangements 
15.  The EA will be the NMSA. The consultants will work together with NMSA staff. The EA 
will provide in-kind resources through the provision of full time counterpart staff, office space 
and administrative support, logistics and local transport. Regular tripartite (NMSA, ADB and 
consultants) meetings will be held to ensure coordination.  
 
16.  The proposed PPTA processing and implementation schedule is listed in Table A4.4.
